summary: I really love the Killian-Pepper scenes in Iron Man 3 because Killian was the guy who used to ask Pepper out a lot. And then...
body:
I really love the Killian-Pepper scenes in Iron Man 3 because Killian was the guy who used to ask Pepper out a lot. And then he’s back, better looking than before (and u can see that Pepper finds him attractive), and tries to get Stark Industries to invest in extremis.

What was the first thing he did? He pulled Da Moves on Pepper by showing the freaking galaxy. And then what did he do next? He showed her his Big Brain TM which we all know Pepper liked because let’s face it, it DID look really nice.

And he did his pitch, said stuff, did some bla bla and Pepper, even if she doesn’t understand the wonders of science half the time, spotted the implications of extremis. Because working with Tony for more than a decade has taught her that anything can be a weapon, really.

Like, just because you showed her ur Big Brain and the galaxy doesnt mean those two things are all she’s gonna think about if SI invests in extremis. Did Killian really think she would say yes to extremis bec pretty brains, space, and medical possibilities?

She knows what killian’s all about. She knows Da Moves when it’s pulled on her.

“It’s also weaponizable,” she says. And SI doesn’t do weapons. Not anymore.

And Killian, pulls a Dick Move. He’s thinking that if he appeals to Pepper’s lesser-than-Tony’s ego, he can actually get Pepper Potts to change her mind. Which would normally work on dick carrying people (hence the name Dick Move) who have fragile egos and balls but not on Pepper Potts.

So, she lets him do his moves and takes a breath (she gets this sort of treatment a lot from other businessmen) and says “It’ll be a no.”

And even when she already said NO, Killian does something worse. He kidnaps her and then violates her by injecting her with extremis. And what did SHE do in return? She freaking destroyed him.

I love it.

summary: "After the deed was done, Ikol-Loki - the third Loki - found himself trapped in the shape of his victim, playing the role of the...
body:
“After the deed was done, Ikol-Loki - the third Loki - found himself trapped in the shape of his victim, playing the role of the good trickster despite his worst intentions. And though he changed that shape - aging to young-manhood - he was still tormented by shame and guilt and self-loathing. By the echo of a final scream - Kid Loki’s accusation that he could never truly change.

So he tried to be better. He tried to change. He tried to grow. And to this end, he made a deal with the All-Mother, to perform missions for Asgard to erase his evil past. And so was born…

…The Agent of Asgard.”

📷: Studio byMarije

summary:
Steve: I have no costume for Halloween...
Tony: You can wear your old suit or try to be Thor at the party?
Steve: Can I just go...
body:
Steve: I have no costume for Halloween…

Tony: You can wear your old suit or try to be Thor at the party?

Steve: Can I just go to the party as your boyfriend instead?

Tony: *softly*

Holy shit.

Thanks for Submitting!

Follow me on twitter @/notcorrectmcu

blog.description: I'm pansexual. Reanna is my name. 22. Virgo. Nonbinary. They/them. Liam is my number 1! Star Trek is my life. Spirk shipper. Zachary Quinto is amazing and Beautiful. I love Little Mix, Rixton, Years and Years, Clean Bandit, I like 5sos, All Time Low, R5, Ed Sheeran, and Adam Lambert. I reblog random posts :). I draw and write :). I love taking Selfies. Hate on me, and I'll probably cry.... My mom doesn't believe that I am Pansexual. :( My dad doesn't know. Liam Payne is sexy and I love him. Oh, I don't like Tyler Oakley. :)

title: Draft season...
body:
Sorry I’ve been MIA lately.  I’ve got drafts building up on the back burner and those’ll all see the light of day sooner or later… but let’s talk a different kind of  draft for a sec.

(Hey! if you’re not familiar with this weird superhero blog, Start Here!  The babble that follows will make marginally more sense that way, I promise.)

Justice Leagues: American, European, International, and Dark, etc…?

Avengers: West Coast, Great Lakes, Young, Dark, and Secret…? 

Titans, Guardians, and Legions?  (of Teen, Galactic, and -of Superheroes persuasions)

A smorgasbord of Corps?

S.H.I.E.L.D.s?  Checkmates? and so-ons and so-forths? 

A big question I haven’t really addressed is how teams work with Collusion.  A lot of character relationships have carried over from either side which makes for a bit of a tangled mess.  So, for a while I’ve wrestled with the idea of whether I keep some and drop others on an arbitrary basis, or do I abandon Marvel and DC teams to make Collusion’s own original teams based on the potential character dynamics we can find or forge therein?  

Some teams make for a nice open but sturdy framework to springboard off of, other have next to nothing really holding them together other than a publication title, and for others still the team itself justifies or defines most of the characters in it.  For example, the Justice League and Avengers are both fairly arbitrary teams with no strong links apart from publication and some fun banter, but those character dynamics and mixed power sets really create the unique team element with room for growth and exploration.

But then there are teams like Teen Titans, Young Justice, Young Avengers, and even Champions which only really function if certain other teams precede them.  Whether they’re a jr. team, a regional variant or special task squad, or in some cases spoofs or other in-world jabs at other teams. 

And groups like The X-Men, Doom Patrol, The Fantastic Four, and such can almost only exist as teams rather than as individual characters.  Trying to find ways to translate those dynamics into a cast of characters that’s only half related is always a unique challenge.

(Once again, the fact that [Bat Family/The X-men] was one of our earliest fusions still finds ways to leave me in awe of how neatly those two very convoluted component pieces actually fit into place together, while other smaller casts of characters (and ones with less individual history to boot) have somehow proven so much harder to sort out)

So here’s a question:

Who are some of your favorite hero teams, and what do you think makes a good hero team really work?

But then there are teams like Teen Titans, Young Justice, Young Avengers, and even Champions which only really function if certain other teams precede them.  Whether they’re a jr. team, a regional variant or special task squad, or in some cases spoofs or other in-world jabs at other teams. 

And groups like The X-Men, Doom Patrol, The Fantastic Four, and such can almost only exist as teams rather than as individual characters.  Trying to find ways to translate those dynamics into a cast of characters that’s only half related is always a unique challenge.

(Once again, the fact that [Bat Family/The X-men] was one of our earliest fusions still finds ways to leave me in awe of how neatly those two very convoluted component pieces actually fit into place together, while other smaller casts of characters (and ones with less individual history to boot) have somehow proven so much harder to sort out)

So here’s a question:

Who are some of your favorite hero teams, and what do you think makes a good hero team really work?
trail.content:
Sorry I’ve been MIA lately.  I’ve got drafts building up on the back burner and those’ll all see the light of day sooner or later… but let’s talk a different kind of  draft for a sec.

(Hey! if you’re not familiar with this weird superhero blog, Start Here!  The babble that follows will make marginally more sense that way, I promise.)

Justice Leagues: American, European, International, and Dark, etc…?

Avengers: West Coast, Great Lakes, Young, Dark, and Secret…? 

Titans, Guardians, and Legions?  (of Teen, Galactic, and -of Superheroes persuasions)

A smorgasbord of Corps?

S.H.I.E.L.D.s?  Checkmates? and so-ons and so-forths? 

A big question I haven’t really addressed is how teams work with Collusion.  A lot of character relationships have carried over from either side which makes for a bit of a tangled mess.  So, for a while I’ve wrestled with the idea of whether I keep some and drop others on an arbitrary basis, or do I abandon Marvel and DC teams to make Collusion’s own original teams based on the potential character dynamics we can find or forge therein?  

Some teams make for a nice open but sturdy framework to springboard off of, other have next to nothing really holding them together other than a publication title, and for others still the team itself justifies or defines most of the characters in it.  For example, the Justice League and Avengers are both fairly arbitrary teams with no strong links apart from publication and some fun banter, but those character dynamics and mixed power sets really create the unique team element with room for growth and exploration.

But then there are teams like Teen Titans, Young Justice, Young Avengers, and even Champions which only really function if certain other teams precede them.  Whether they’re a jr. team, a regional variant or special task squad, or in some cases spoofs or other in-world jabs at other teams. 

And groups like The X-Men, Doom Patrol, The Fantastic Four, and such can almost only exist as teams rather than as individual characters.  Trying to find ways to translate those dynamics into a cast of characters that’s only half related is always a unique challenge.

(Once again, the fact that [Bat Family/The X-men] was one of our earliest fusions still finds ways to leave me in awe of how neatly those two very convoluted component pieces actually fit into place together, while other smaller casts of characters (and ones with less individual history to boot) have somehow proven so much harder to sort out)

So here’s a question:

Who are some of your favorite hero teams, and what do you think makes a good hero team really work?
trail.content_abstract:
Sorry I’ve been MIA lately.  I’ve got drafts building up on the back burner and those’ll all see the light of day sooner or later… but let’s talk a different kind of  draft for a sec.

(Hey! if you’re not familiar with this weird superhero blog, Start Here!  The babble that follows will make marginally more sense that way, I promise.)
